survey_questions.question: How does your organization establish and maintain its information security governance framework, ensuring management approval, communication to staff, and regular reviews?
answer_set: We have no formally documented information security policies.
Policies exist but are not formally approved by management, are outdated, or are not communicated effectively to all personnel.
Information security policies are defined, approved by management, and communicated to staff. Reviews happen, but on an ad-hoc basis.

A comprehensive set of security policies is defined, approved, published, and regularly reviewed (at least annually or upon significant change). All personnel are required to formally acknowledge them.

relevant_controls.title: Policies for information security
relevant_controls.description: Information security policy and topic-specific policies shall be defined, approved by management, published, communicated to and acknowledged by relevant personnel and relevant interested parties, and reviewed at planned intervals and if significant changes occur.

survey_questions.question: How are information security roles, responsibilities, and segregation of duties defined and enforced within your organization, particularly for handling sensitive financial data and transactions?
answer_set: Roles and responsibilities are not formally defined; staff perform multiple, potentially conflicting duties.
Responsibilities are informally understood, but not documented. Segregation of duties is attempted but not systematically enforced.
Key roles and responsibilities are documented, and a formal policy for segregation of duties exists for critical financial functions.

All information security roles are formally defined, allocated, and integrated into job descriptions. Conflicting duties (e.g., transaction initiation and approval) are strictly segregated and enforced through technical and procedural controls.

relevant_controls.title: Information security roles and responsibilities
relevant_controls.description: Information security roles and responsibilities shall be defined and allocated according to the organization needs.

relevant_controls.title: Segregation of duties
relevant_controls.description: Conflicting duties and conflicting areas of responsibility shall be segregated.

survey_questions.question: How does your firm manage the lifecycle of user identities and access rights to financial systems and data, from onboarding to termination?
answer_set: Access is granted using shared or generic accounts, and rights are rarely revoked upon termination.
User accounts are created and removed manually. Access rights are granted based on request, not a formal role, and reviews are infrequent.
A formal process exists for provisioning and de-provisioning access based on roles. Access rights are reviewed periodically (e.g., quarterly).

We use an automated Identity and Access Management (IAM) system that enforces role-based access control (RBAC) and the principle of least privilege. Access rights are provisioned automatically upon hiring, reviewed regularly, and revoked immediately upon termination.

relevant_controls.title: Access control
relevant_controls.description: Rules to control physical and logical access to information and other associated assets shall be established and implemented based on business and information security requirements.

relevant_controls.title: Identity management
relevant_controls.description: The full life cycle of identities shall be managed.

relevant_controls.title: Access rights
relevant_controls.description: Access rights to information and other associated assets shall be provisioned, reviewed, modified and removed in accordance with the organization’s topic-specific policy on and rules for access control.

NIST SP 1800-2 – Access Rights Management for the Financial Services Sector

survey_questions.question: What is your approach to identifying, classifying, and handling information assets, particularly customer financial data and intellectual property?
answer_set: We do not maintain an inventory of our information assets, and there is no classification scheme.
An informal inventory of assets exists. Some sensitive data is recognized, but there are no formal rules for its acceptable use or handling.
We maintain an inventory of key information assets with assigned owners. A classification scheme (e.g., Public, Internal, Confidential, Restricted) is defined and applied to major datasets.

A comprehensive, up-to-date inventory of all information assets is maintained. All data is classified, labelled, and handled according to formal acceptable use and information transfer rules based on its classification level.

relevant_controls.title: Inventory of information and other associated assets
relevant_controls.description: An inventory of information and other associated assets, including owners, shall be developed and maintained.

relevant_controls.title: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
relevant_controls.description: Rules for the acceptable use and procedures for handling information and other associated assets shall be identified, documented and implemented.

relevant_controls.title: Classification of information
relevant_controls.description: Information shall be classified according to the information security needs of the organization based on confidentiality, integrity, availability and relevant interested party requirements.

relevant_controls.title: Labelling of information
relevant_controls.description: An appropriate set of procedures for information labelling shall be developed and implemented in accordance with the information classification scheme adopted by the organization.

NIST NCCoE Project: Data Classification Practices

priority_justification.title: FIPS 199 – Standards for Security Categorization of Information

survey_questions.question: How does your organization manage information security risks associated with third-party suppliers, from initial due diligence to ongoing monitoring?
answer_set: We do not perform security assessments of our suppliers, even those handling sensitive financial data.
Security is discussed with critical suppliers, but requirements are not included in contracts and there is no ongoing monitoring.
We perform due diligence on new suppliers and include baseline security requirements in our agreements. Monitoring is informal and infrequent.

A comprehensive supplier risk management program is in place. It includes mandatory security assessments, contractual security clauses, regular monitoring of supplier performance, and management of risks in the ICT supply chain.

relevant_controls.title: Information security in supplier relationships
relevant_controls.description: Processes and procedures shall be defined and implemented to manage the information security risks associated with the use of supplier’s products or services.

relevant_controls.title: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
relevant_controls.description: Relevant information security requirements shall be established and agreed with each supplier based on the type of supplier relationship.

relevant_controls.title: Managing information security in the ICT supply chain
relevant_controls.description: Processes and procedures shall be defined and implemented to manage the information security risks associated with the ICT products and services supply chain.

relevant_controls.title: Monitoring, review and change management of supplier services
relevant_controls.description: The organization shall regularly monitor, review, evaluate and manage change in supplier information security practices and service delivery.

CISA ICT Supply-Chain Risk Management Essentials

priority_justification.title: ISO 27001:2022 Annex A 5.21 – Managing Information Security in the ICT Supply Chain

survey_questions.question: What is your firm's process for handling the full lifecycle of information security incidents, from initial detection and assessment to response and forensic evidence collection?
answer_set: We have no formal incident response plan.
We react to incidents as they occur but lack a documented process, defined roles, or evidence collection procedures.
An incident response plan is documented with defined roles. Events are assessed to determine if they are incidents, and a response is coordinated.
We have a comprehensive, tested incident management plan. This includes 24/7 monitoring, formal event assessment, documented response procedures, and forensically sound evidence collection processes.

relevant_controls.title: Information security incident management planning and preparation
relevant_controls.description: The organization shall plan and prepare for managing information security incidents by defining, establishing and communicating information security incident management processes, roles and responsibilities.

relevant_controls.title: Assessment and decision on information security events
relevant_controls.description: The organization shall assess information security events and decide if they are to be categorized as information security incidents.

relevant_controls.title: Response to information security incidents
relevant_controls.description: Information security incidents shall be responded to in accordance with the documented procedures.

relevant_controls.title: Collection of evidence
relevant_controls.description: The organization shall establish and implement procedures for the identification, collection, acquisition and preservation of evidence related to information security events.

survey_questions.question: How do you ensure your organization identifies and complies with all legal, regulatory (e.g., GDPR, PCI-DSS), and contractual requirements related to information security and PII protection?
answer_set: We are not actively tracking legal or regulatory requirements relevant to our operations.
We are aware of some major regulations but do not have a formal process to document and ensure compliance.
A process is in place to identify and document relevant legal and contractual requirements, including those for PII. Compliance is reviewed periodically.

We maintain a comprehensive register of all legal, statutory, regulatory, and contractual requirements, which is regularly updated. Proactive processes and independent reviews are in place to ensure ongoing compliance.

relevant_controls.title: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
relevant_controls.description: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements relevant to information security and the organization’s approach to meet these requirements shall be identified, documented and kept up to date.

relevant_controls.title: Privacy and protection of personally identifiable information (PII)
relevant_controls.description: The organization shall identify and meet the requirements regarding the preservation of privacy and protection of PII according to applicable laws and regulations and contractual requirements.

survey_questions.question: What measures are in place to manage the human resources aspect of security, including background screening, security clauses in contracts, and awareness training?
answer_set: We do not perform background checks, include security responsibilities in contracts, or provide security training.
Background checks are conducted for some roles. Security is mentioned during onboarding but not formalized in contracts or regular training.
Background checks are standard procedure, employment contracts include confidentiality and security responsibility clauses, and annual security awareness training is provided.

A robust HR security process is in place including ongoing screening for sensitive roles, clearly defined security responsibilities in contracts, and a continuous security awareness program with role-specific training and phishing simulations.

relevant_controls.title: Screening
relevant_controls.description: Background verification checks on all candidates shall be carried out prior to joining the organization and on an ongoing basis, considering laws, regulations, business needs, and perceived risks.

relevant_controls.title: Terms and conditions of employment
relevant_controls.description: The employment contractual agreements shall state the personnel’s and the organization’s responsibilities for information security.

relevant_controls.title: Information security awareness, education and training
relevant_controls.description: Personnel and relevant interested parties shall receive appropriate information security awareness, education, and training, including updates of the organization's policies and procedures relevant to their job function.

question_relevance.title: Financial Services Background Checks – A Complete Guide
CISA Cybersecurity Training & Exercises

priority_justification.title: ISO 27001:2022 Annex A 6.1 – Screening
ISO 27001:2022 Annex A 6.3 – Security Awareness, Education & Training

survey_questions.question: How does your organization manage sensitive data on physical storage media and ensure the secure disposal or re-use of equipment containing financial information?
answer_set: Storage media and old equipment are disposed of without any data removal process.
We attempt to delete files from equipment before disposal, but there is no formal or verified process.
A formal policy exists for managing storage media throughout its lifecycle. Equipment is wiped using standard software before disposal or re-use.

All storage media is managed based on its data classification. A certified data destruction process (e.g., degaussing, physical shredding) is used for all media containing sensitive financial data, and a certificate of destruction is retained.

relevant_controls.title: Storage media
relevant_controls.description: Managed through their life cycle: acquisition, use, transport, disposal based on classification and handling needs.

relevant_controls.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
relevant_controls.description: Sensitive data and licensed software must be verified as removed before disposal or re-use.

survey_questions.question: What technical controls are implemented to restrict access to information, protect against malware, and manage system configurations securely?
answer_set: No specific technical controls are in place; we rely on default system settings.
Basic antivirus software is installed, but there are no formal processes for access restriction or configuration management.
Access to sensitive data is restricted, enterprise-grade anti-malware is deployed, and secure configurations are defined for key systems.

A multi-layered defense is in place including: strict access controls, advanced endpoint protection (EDR), proactive vulnerability management, and automated configuration management to enforce hardened system builds.

relevant_controls.title: Information access restriction
relevant_controls.description: Access to information and other associated assets shall be restricted in accordance with the established topic-specific policy on access control.

relevant_controls.title: Protection against malware
relevant_controls.description: Protection against malware shall be implemented and supported by appropriate user awareness.

relevant_controls.title: Configuration management
relevant_controls.description: Configurations of hardware, software, and networks shall be securely defined, monitored and reviewed.

survey_questions.question: How are cryptographic controls, such as encryption and data masking, used to protect sensitive customer and transactional data both at rest and in transit?
answer_set: We do not use encryption or other cryptographic controls.
Encryption is used in some specific instances (e.g., website HTTPS) but not as a general policy for sensitive data.
A policy for the use of cryptography is in place. Sensitive data is encrypted at rest in databases and in transit over public networks. Data masking is used in test environments.

Comprehensive cryptographic controls are implemented based on data classification. This includes strong encryption for all data at rest and in transit, robust key management processes, data masking for non-production use, and regular reviews of cryptographic standards.

relevant_controls.title: Data masking
relevant_controls.description: Data masking shall follow access control policies and business/legal requirements.

relevant_controls.title: Use of cryptography
relevant_controls.description: Rules for cryptographic controls (e.g., key management) shall be defined and implemented.

relevant_controls.title: Data leakage prevention
relevant_controls.description: Data leakage prevention measures shall protect systems and networks handling sensitive data.

survey_questions.question: What is your firm's strategy for data backup, disaster recovery, and ensuring ICT readiness for business continuity?
answer_set: We have no data backup or business continuity plans.
Data backups are performed irregularly and are not tested. A continuity plan exists on paper but has never been exercised.
Regular, automated backups are performed and stored off-site. A business continuity plan is documented and key ICT systems have identified recovery objectives (RTO/RPO).

A comprehensive business continuity and disaster recovery strategy is in place. It includes fully redundant systems, automated backups that are regularly tested for restorability, and a full DR exercise conducted at least annually to ensure ICT readiness.

relevant_controls.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
relevant_controls.description: ICT readiness shall be planned, implemented, maintained and tested based on business continuity objectives and ICT continuity requirements.

relevant_controls.title: Information backup
relevant_controls.description: Backup of data and systems shall be maintained and tested regularly.

survey_questions.question: How do you ensure the security of the software development lifecycle, from writing secure code to separating development, testing, and production environments?
answer_set: Developers have no security training, and all work is done in a single, shared environment.
We have some informal coding guidelines, but no security testing. Development and production environments are logically separated.

Secure coding principles are defined and developers are trained. Development, test, and production environments are physically or virtually separated. Some security testing is performed before release.

A formal Secure Development Life Cycle (SDLC) is implemented. This includes mandatory secure coding training, static/dynamic application security testing (SAST/DAST), managed access to source code, and strictly enforced separation and change management for all environments.

relevant_controls.title: Secure development life cycle
relevant_controls.description: Secure development rules shall be established and applied for software and systems.

relevant_controls.title: Secure coding
relevant_controls.description: Secure coding principles shall be enforced.

relevant_controls.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
relevant_controls.description: Development, test, and production environments shall be separated and secured.

relevant_controls.title: Change management
relevant_controls.description: All changes to information systems shall follow a change management procedure.
